awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CNS Core: Small: Secure and Efficient Mobile Edge Computing in Wireless Heterogeneous Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Future wireless networks will support massive energy-limited computation-constrained user equipment that are often required to execute latency sensitive yet computation-intensive tasks. Although technologies that can elevate local device computation capability and battery capacity have been substantially pushed forward, there still exists a huge gap between the high computation/processing demands and the low computation/battery capacities in user equipment. Mobile edge computing (MEC) allows user equipment to offload partial or complete computation-intensive tasks to the edge computing servers to save power and reduce latency. Inspired by recent advances in wireless technologies and challenges, the proposed research aims to explore a novel framework that can jointly consider communications and computations in a mobile edge computing-based wireless heterogeneous network to realize secure and efficient offloading and achieve desirable trade-offs among computation throughput, computation efficiency, latency, and user fairness.  The proposed research activities have significant potentials to revolutionize the next generation wireless network design by jointly considering edge computations and communications in delivering secure, latency critical, computation-intensive applications such as augmented reality/virtual reality, connected and autonomous vehicle, and remote medical diagnosis. It can significantly facilitate the understanding in the field of emerging mobile edge networks, which will play a key role in the modem society to realize smart environments with computation intensive mobile applications. 

The proposed research framework develops secure multiple access schemes during offloading, computation coordination and scheduling schemes for selecting user equipment and computation tasks to offload. The research will identify unique technical challenges and explore many new aspects in the mobile edge computing enabled wireless heterogenous networks, including  non-orthogonal multiple access, computing offloading mode selection, success interference cancellation decoding order design, hybrid multiple access analysis, and heterogeneous MEC coordination, driven by joint consideration on security, efficiency, and user fairness.  The theoretical framework formulation and analysis, engineering design guidelines for practical implementation and deployment will be obtained, and prototyping/simulation tools will be shared with the scientific research and engineering communities. The success of this project can greatly advance the understanding of the critical issues in the mobile edge computing-based wireless network design and contribute a new resource allocation framework that can remarkably improve the performance of future wireless network computing. The project will also both undergraduate and graduate students research opportunities with developing and deploying new wireless network technologies, thus serving the growing need for educating and training students, especially female students and students from underrepresented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated mobile edge computing (MEC) environments in wireless heterogeneous networks with secure and efficient schemes. The proposed research aims at developing novel efficienct and secure multiple access schemes during offloading, computation coordination and scheduling schemes for selecting user equipment and computation tasks to offload, in both traditional wireless networks and also wireless networks that aims to support distributed AI. The approaches focus on identifying unique technical challenges and exploring new aspects of MEC in wireless heterogeneous networks. Key areas of investigation include non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA), computation offloading mode selection, interference cancellation decoding order design, hybrid multiple access analysis, and heterogeneous MEC coordination. These efforts are driven by a joint consideration of security, efficiency, and user fairness. Simulation tools were developed to evaluate performance trade-offs and validate theoretical results for secure and efficient MEC  in wireless heterogeneous networks. Theoretical studies were conducted to achieve optimal performance for MEC in wireless networks, and practical engineering design rules and guidelines for the implementation and deployment of secure and efficient MEC were also derived.


During the four years of the project, the project team investigated  some most challenging issues of emerging mobile edge computing-based wireless network design, and studied various offloading efficiency and offloading security aspects and achieve desirable trade-offs among computation throughput, computation efficiency, latency, and user fairness. More specifically, various research activities were conducted:
-   Secure computation efficiency driven computation offloading with OFDMA access
-   Secure computation efficiency driven computation offloading with NOMA access
-   Secure computation efficiency driven offloading with a hybrid multiple access
-  Secure computation efficiency and secure computation throughput driven partial computation offloading
-  Secure computation efficiency and execution cost driven partial computation offloading
-  Multi-objective driven binary computation offloading
-  Secure computation efficiency driven offloading and coordination
-  Secure computation efficiency and user fairness driven computation offloading and coordination
-  Secure computation efficiency driven robust computation offloading and coordination
- Develop secure and efficient federated learning framework in the mobile edge computing
- Develop secure and efficient semantic communications framework in the mobile edge computing
- Apply the secure and efficient communication and ML schemes in MEC to electrified transportation

The research activities have resulted significant potentials to enhancing the mobile edge computing-based wireless network design and contributing a new resource allocation framework that can remarkably improve the spectrum efficiency, energy efficiency, computation efficiency, and also latency performance of future wireless networks.  The research has also improved security and privacy in mobile edge computing paradigm, which is one of the most important requirements for the MEC services. The resseach has achieved secure and privacy-preserving computation offloading while optimizing performance metrics such as secure computation efficiency, secure computation throughput, and user fairness. These metrics are expected to play a key role in designing future wireless networks that handle the explosive amount of data collected from local and personal devices, which are highly sensitive to security and privacy concerns.

The PI, Rose Hu, is affiliated with the NSF ASPIRE Engineering Research Center and has been working closely with the team to apply secure and efficient MEC (Mobile Edge Computing) technologies in electrified transportation. The research in this area aims to facilitate efficient and secure off-road and dynamic on-road charging through advanced communications and computational technologies.

In total, four PhD students have been partially supported through this project. These students received valuable training in cutting-edge fields such as wireless edge computing, federated learning, and semantic communications. Their experience included hands-on work in algorithm development, the implementation of simulation software, the creation of analysis tools, as well as conducting experiments and interpreting results. Through these activities, they gained practical skills and theoretical knowledge that are highly relevant to both academia and industry. Two of the PhD students have since secured tenure-track faculty positions at U.S. institutions, further demonstrating the success and impact of the training provided through this project.

The PI has been updating the course materials for both undergraduate and graduate courses she has been teaching at Utah State University. She has also given two invited talks at the Utah Women4STEM conferences (2023 and 2024), primarily targeting K-12 female students, where she introduced related research conducted through this project and its applications to electrified transportation.
